notes: Change to armed group: On 19 December 2020, leaders of the 3 main armed rebel groups occupying large areas of CAR, namely the Anti-Balaka, 3R and MPC, announced a coalition, called the Coalition of Patriots for Change or CPC, ahead of the 27 December elections. The armed groups had decided 'to combine all of our movements into a single entity and under a unified command, and invited 'all other armed groups to join'. The groups accused President Faustin-Archange Touadera's government of seeking to fix upcoming elections and warned of a violent response. The coalition vowed not to attack civilians and to allow vehicles belonging to the United Nations and to humanitarian groups to circulate freely. Location is coded to Bangui (Bangui, Bangui).

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 6 August 2020, the Central African Republic Prime Minister signed an agreement in Bangui (Banui, Bangui) with the leader of the UPC (Union for Peace in the Central African Republic) armed group, Ali Darass. The latter committed not to hinder the return of state authority as well as the free movement of agents of the ANE (National Election Authority) before the upcoming election. In exchange, among other agreements, this armed group was allowed to return to Bambari (Ouaka), their former headquarters.

On 5 August 2020, the UN Security Council voted to impose sanctions on Sidiki Abbas, the leader of the 3R armed group (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation). The group, who withdrew from a peace agreement in June 2020, was accused of killing, torturing, raping and displacing civilians as well as engaging in arms trafficking and in war with other militias since its creation in 2015.

On 25 June 2019, in Batangafo, 1 INGO staff member was assaulted and injured after anti-Balaka armed actors broke into his home. During the armed incursion, four others in the home were robbed of their mobile phones, cash, and other items. The staff member received medical treatment at a local hospital, and the perpetrators were handed over to MINUSCA by a local anti-Balaka leader.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: On 19 June 2019, in Bangui, unidentified men have attempted to kidnap minister of livestock of CAR. The victim has narrowly escaped.

On 18 June 2019, in Kpabou [coordinates are approximate based on CT map], an LRA group, comprised of women, children, and 7 armed men, looted a field. The group looted maize and peanuts. The assailants spoke Acholi and Zande, and were dressed in civilian and military attire. The group left heading east towards Mboki.

On 17 June 2019, an LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children looted field camps 10 km southeast of Mboki. The assailants looted cassava, maize and peanuts. They spoke Acholi, Zande, and broken Sango. Some were armed with AK-47s.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

assoc_actor_2: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic); Farmers (Central African Republic)
notes: On 10 June 2019, a suspected LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children, attacked a Peuhl camp 4 km northwest of Obo. The assailants stole 4 cattle from the victims. They also looted a nearby field. The farmers of the land fled upon sighting the armed group.

On 10 June 2019, an LRA group, comprised of 3 armed men and 16 unarmed boys, looted fields southwest of Obo. The assailants held 14 civilians, including 2 mothers with 3 children, for several hours. The group released 9 of the civilians but abducted the 5 remaining men.

The group is one of the 14 armed groups that signed the Sudan Peace and Unity Accord with the CAR government on February 5. The killings caused international outcry and statements by MINUSCA and CAR Government's ultimatum to the leader of the group to hand culprits.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

08 March (on or before). KM5 militiamen led by Mahamat alias LT clashed with street traders in the KM 5 market in Bangui. The clash occurred as LT's members sought to extort money from the traders. Grenades and automatic weapons were utilized during the clash.
07 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia robbed a trader who was leaving the Boulangba, Basse Kotto to travel to Mobaye. The event triggered clashes with the UPC (coded separately).

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 7 March 2019, as well as 9 March 2019, the Boulangba self-defense militia clashed with UPC forces in Boulangba and Kandia in Basse Kotto (unclear if clashes in both villages on both days; coded as two events, one in Boulangba prec1 on 7 March, one in Boulangba prec2 on 9 March as no coordinates available for Kandia). Houses were also burned down. Six combatants - five from the self-defense group and one UPC fighter- were killed during the clashes. The fatalities are spread between the two events.
05 March. An unidentified 'rebel' group from CAR blocked the road between Bouar in CAR and Garoua - Boulai in Cameroon.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 04 March 2019. UPC forces abducted Soulemane Daouda, the Livestock and Health Minister, in Gbokologbo (no coordinates available; 60 km from Alindao).

The UPC expressed similar displeasure with the new prime minister, Firmin Ngrebada (a close ally of Touadera) but did not withdraw from the process.

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 03 March 2019. Members of a self-defense group in Boulangba seized the weapon of a UPC commander in Boulangba, Basse Kotto. The event triggered clashes with the UPC (coded separately).
03 March 2019. The LRA looted 10 civilians a long a road near the Yangou Bakoya mine (approx. Coordinates based on location 68 km east of Sam Ouandja and shown on source map).
02 March. 3R combatants killed three hunters and injured a fourth in Bouzou, Ouham Pende.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 01 March (on or around). KM5 militiamen led by Mahamat alias LT injured a Muslim soldier and the leader of a Muslim youth group in Bangui.
01 March. Two 3R militia members shot and killed a motor taxi driver in Makouzi Ouali (no coordinates available), 20 km from Bocaranga. The assailants then stole the victim's motorcycle.
On 27 February 2019, unidentified armed men assaulted and injured 1 INGO staff member in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto) during an incursion into an INGO's project site.

actor1: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2016-) Customs Office
notes: 27 February. A customs official shot and killed an economic operator in the customs office in Gamboula. An investigation was launched into the shooting.

assoc_actor_2: ANECA: National Central African Students Association; Students (Central African Republic)
notes: 26 February. Members of the ANECA vandalized the organization's office in Bangui, following an internal dispute over the requirements to run for president of the organization.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 24 February. After the death of Mandakara, an Anti-Balaka leader, the group clashed with the UPC in Kouango. Several casualties reported.
23 February 2019. The LRA ambushed and looted four traders, 18 km from Pambayamba, Haute-Kotto.
21 February 2019. The LRA looted food and goods at the Chantier Confluent mine, 25 km north of Mbangana while civilians fled.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 21 February. A police officer stopped three men on a motorbike at a checkpoint in Boda. One of the passengers had a weapon, which the police ordered the man to surrender. When the man refused, the police shot and killed two of the men.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: 21 February. After a police officer shot and killed two people at a checkpoint, angry youth in Boda burned the Gendarmerie barracks and ransacked police station and customs office. Number of demonstrators not reported.

actor1: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 20 February. The humanitarian corridor along the Mobaye-Kongbo road in Basse-Kotto was reopened following an agreement between the local government and armed groups (UPC and Anti-Balaka).

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.
18 February 2019. An unidentified armed group shot at a man and woman on a bike along the Bria-Nzako road, near Manzala. The man was injured.
18 February. Five trader went missing. Their bodies were discovered on 23/02 near Bozongui, Haut Mbomou. The bodies appeared to have been murdered.
13 February. LRA combatants attacked Ligoua, Obo. The perpetrators looted the town and abducted three civilians.
12 February 2019. An LRA group - consisting of five women and five men - attacked Ligoua, Haut-Mbomou. The assailants looted goods and abducted three people, including one child.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.

assoc_actor_1: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 11 February. Retired soldiers demonstrated in Bangui over the delay of payments owed to them by the government.

08 February. Suspected Sudanese poachers killed three Fulani, including a 9 year old child, 20 km outside of Obo. The assailants also robbed two non-Muslims in the area, who returned to Obo and reported the event to MINUSCA. The family of the Fulani victims suspect the involvement of those who reported the incident. However, there is a long-standing dispute between Fulani and Sudanese poachers which others report as the reasoning for the killing of the Fulani and release of the Christians.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
notes: 06 February. Seven prisoners escaped from the Carnot prison, by breaking through a wall.

notes: 06 February. 14 armed groups signed a peace agreement with the CAR government in Bangui. The agreement calls for the establishment of an 'inclusive' government, as well as the creation of a truth and reconciliation commission.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.
02 February. A convoy of humanitarian vehicles was looted by an armed group 5 km south of Kaga Bandoro.
01 February. An unidentified armed group moved into Dogo (no coordinates available; 10 km from Bouar). FACA deployed in response but were unable to access the village.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
notes: 31 January. During the night, 18 prisoners escaped from the Mbaiki prison.

30 January. Thousands of protesters gathered in Bossangoa to demonstrate against the arms embargo currently imposed on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.
29 January. An unidentified armed group robbed humanitarian workers in Boguidi, Ouham.

29 January. Residents of Berberati protested calling for the removal of the arms embargo on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.

28 January. Thousands of protesters demonstrated in Bangui, calling for the removal of the arms embargo on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.

assoc_actor_2: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
notes: 28 January. LRA forces attacked a Fulani family 42 km southeast of Sam Ouandja, Haute Kotto. The assailants abducted two boys and stole four cattle. One of the boys was later released after the attackers severely assaulted him.
28 January. An unidentified armed group robbed an NGO team in Gbadene, Ouham.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 26 January. After fleeing Bambari, UPC fighters killed two civilians in Yamalet (no coordinates available), 30 km from Bambari along the Bambari-Balaka road.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 25 January. The UPC commander in Ippy executed the UPC soldier who killed 13 civilians the day prior.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 24 January. A drunken UPC soldier opened fire on civilians at a funeral in the Djama-Yakania neighborhood of Ippy. 13 civilians were killed and approximately 20 others were shot and injured (other sources indicate a greater number of casualties).
24 January. Bambari residents protested in front of the MINUSCA base with the three bodies of civilians killed during clashes between the peacekeepers and the UPC the night prior.
24 January. An Anti-Balaka group killed three civilians, including a woman and child, along a road near Alindao.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

22 January. After a robber killed two children, local residents caught the robber and killed him.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: 20 January. Sidiki's 3R forces and armed Fulani attacked Zaoro Sangou, killing at least 13 people including two gendarmerie soldiers (some sources indicated 14 fatalities).

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

18 January. An armed group carried out four robberies in the Beta and Saint-Jean neighborhoods. The perpetrators killed two people, including a humanitarian worker.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

notes: 16 January. A joint MINUSCA-FACA force regained control of Bakouma after an early morning incursion into the town. Bakouma had been occupied by the UPC and FPRC since the end of December.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: Around 13 January 2019 (week of), FACA forces detained a trader in Bambari (Bambari, Ouaka), who was accused by locals of being an ex-Seleka member. The man was then taken to a FACA base, where Russian mercenaries, believed to be from the Wagner group, detained and tortured the man using knives, chains, bricks and batons. The man was later freed by Internal Security Forces. The UN launched an investigation.
12 January. An unidentified armed group killed three Fulani, including two women, near Zaorossoungou.

MSF reported four wounded and one fatality during the day. Additional UPC fighters were reported around Bambari in the next days, entering the city in civilian attire and vehicles.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 11 January. A trader in Ouanda Djalle threw a grenade at local authorities who were arguing if they should turn taxes they collected to the government offices or to armed groups. One person was killed by the grenade and others were injured.

10 January (on or around). Armed groups clashed in Bokagnan (coordinates are approximate based on location being 45 km east of Bouar, along the Bouar-Bozoum road). Over 1,000 residents were displaced.
10 January. An armed group robbed humanitarian workers 30 km north of Bouar. The perpetrators stole money intended for beneficiaries and personal belongings.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: 10 January (on or around). During the FPRC's occupation of Bakouma (from late December until 16/01), 32 people were killed - including five women. 20 fatalities coded in two separate VAC events in January and 12 fatalities included in armed clash reported on December 31st.

assoc_actor_2: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
notes: 09 January. A grenade was thrown into a truck of Fulani herders, on the road between Bangui and Boali. Two people were killed.
09 January. Four people were killed in KM 5, in retaliation for the earlier grenade attack against Fulanis that killed two.
08 January. 3R attacked Bokayan, killing at least five people. A joint FACA/MINUSCA force was deployed the same night in response.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

notes: 08 January. During the night UPC/FPRC forces, occupying Bakouma, clashed with Anti-Balaka forces in the town. Anti-Balaka forces reportedly gained control of part of the city.

notes: 08 January. An armed group ransacked a health facility in Gbadene. The local population fled during the attack. The aid organization supporting the facility has suspended operations in the town.

notes: 07 January 2019. The LRA abducted four women from their fields in Koumboli, Zemio. The assailants released the abductees later that day.
07 January. Residents of Bangassou protested the violence in neighboring Bakouma and called for the withdrawal of armed groups from the near by town.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

The detainees relative then stabbed one of the members of the ex-Seleka group, sparking a clash which left seven wounded.
05 January. During an attempted robbery, an armed group shot and killed a security guard at an NGO office in Batangafo.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: 05 January (on or around). During the FPRC's occupation of Bakouma (from late December until 16/01), 32 people were killed - including five women. 20 fatalities coded in two separate VAC events in January and 12 fatalities included in armed clash reported on December 31st.
04 January. Women and children barricaded the road 10km outside of Bakouma to call for the protection of MINUSCA/FACA forces and denounce the occupation of Bakouma by the FPRC/UPC.
04 January. An armed group ambushed and assaulted humanitarian workers 18 km north of Bria along the Irabanda road.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 03 January. Members of the GSTC attempted to gather in Bangui for a demonstration, in conjunction with a three day strike over salaries, but were dispersed by police.

02 January. Moussa Sair (Emperor), a ranking member of the KM5-Force militia was killed during a clash with LT, the leader of another KM5 militia. The clash occurred over the control of a parking area.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 31 December (on or around). The UPC implemented a taxation system for all residents living in areas under their control. In addition to individual resident taxes, fees are also imposed on herders, car owners, farmers, and other small business owners.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
assoc_actor_1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 31 December. UPC and FPRC forces attacked Bakouma and clashed with Anti-Balaka and FACA forces. At least a dozen people were killed (coded as 12), including Sultan Madambari, who had ties to Anti-Balaka forces. Homes were burned and property was looted. Many of the residents fled as the UPC and FPRC took control of the town. Joint MINUSCA/FACA forces deployed the next day to initiate talks.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
assoc_actor_1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: 27 December. UPC and FPRC forces moved into Bakouma (a mining town). Some local sources report they began arriving on 24/12. There are no security or MINUSCA forces in the town, so many civilians fled into the bush.
26 December. The bodies of four men who were missing for a week were discovered at the bottom of a well in Bambari. Some locals suspect that the UPC was responsible for the deaths.

assoc_actor_1: RRR: Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation; Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
notes: 26 December. Armed clash between herders allied to 3R and farmers in Bocarange after a dispute over land damage by their cattle. A gendarme who intervened during the clash was assaulted by the 3R chief.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: 24 December. 3R forces stormed the Gendarmerie base in Bohong and released two Chadian detainees.
22 December. An armed group broke into a humanitarian base in Batangafo and stole goods.

assoc_actor_1: APPAP: Alliance of Parties, Personalities and Political Associations
notes: 19 December. Members of the APPAP demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to show their support for the government and Khartoum negotiations.

actor1: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
assoc_actor_2: UFR: Union of Republican Forces (Central African Republic)
notes: 17 December. The government launched a DDR program in Paoua. Participant groups are expected to include RF factions of Armel Sayo and Belenga (although there is some reports that this is a contentious issue within the Belenga faction), the UFR, and two Anti-Balaka groups.

16 December. A group of LRA members (including three women with babies) ambushed two men and a woman who were on a motorbike 5km west of Guerekindo. The perpetrators killed one of the men, injured the woman, and stole their belongings.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
actor2: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
notes: 16 December. Clashes between the Goula and Ronga or FPRC and RPRC (both ex-Seleka) in Charahibou, 85km from Birao, near the border with Sudan. According to local sources, the Ronga accused the Goula of promoting the government's DDR process. At least five killed.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
actor2: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
notes: 16-24 December. Tensions rose between the Goula and Ronga or FPRC and RPRC (both ex-Seleka) after the FPRC arrested some MLCJ in a camp in the Ouadda-Djalle area. Clashes averted by the intervention of local security forces.
14 December. An armed group looted a humanitarian convoy at Ngadza Toko, along the Kouango-Bianga axis. Humanitarian activities along the road have been suspended following the incident.

13 December. Following the arrest of former Anti-Balaka leader, Edourdo Ngaissona in France, Maxime Mokom released a statement withdrawing his faction's participation in DDR programs and peace negotiations. Ngaissona's faction also released a statement calling for its representatives to withdraw from the DDR program.
13 December. The chief of Pounebanda and his son were killed by an armed group. Over 700 residents fled after the attack.
10 December. A LRA group attacked Ketesia (no coordinates available) in Obo, Haut Mbomou. The group looted supplies and abducted two children. Most of the villagers then fled into the bush.
10 December. Sidiki's 3R forces took up position at the entrance of Bocaranga town. They also moved into strategic positions across Ouham Pende and have blocked the Bocaranga-Bohong road.

actor1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 08 December. Police in Bambari arrested Didier Wangai, the second in command of the UPC, for human rights abuses. This reportedly came after the UPC refused to vacate the town.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 05 December. The UPC set fire to the IDP camp at the Catholic Church in Ippy, which they attacked the day prior. Three people were killed.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 04 December. UPC and Anti-Balaka fighters clashed in Ippy.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 04 December. UPC forces opened fire at IDPs at an IDP camp at the Catholic Church in Ippy. Serious injuries occurred. The UPC denied responsibility for the attack and claimed that bandits in a dispute with a group of armed Fulani herders fled to the site and falsely accused the UPC of attacking them.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 04 December. FACA forces arrived in Bocaranga but after being threatened by Abbas Sidiki (3R) - whose forces are stationed 5km from the city - the soldiers left the city.

03 December. The Be-Afrika Association protested against the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Charles Armel Doubane, in Bangui. They called for the minister's removal after he declined to participate in 01/12 festivities.
03 December. LRA members attacked a diamond mine near Pambayamba. A local ex-Seleka group responded and repelled the LRA.

On 28 November 2018, ex-Seleka militia members attempted to rob a weapons cache from Anti-Balaka members in Batangafo town (Batangafo, Ouham) . An Anti-Balaka member was found killed after the incident, likely armed.

On 27 November 2018, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Bangui militia members shot and killed a trader to avenge the murder of Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia who was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant two days priro.
On 25 November 2018, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant who refused to obey his orders.
24 November. Two aid workers were abducted by an armed group while traveling on the Bria-Irrabanda road. They were released on 03/12.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 22 November. UPC forces clashed with Anti-Balaka in Banangui. Twenty-five homes were burned during the clash and thousands of residents fled.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: 22 November. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA post in the Alindao IDP camp. The combatants exchanged fire with the peacekeepers for 30 minutes before hiding within the camp. One civilian was killed and one was injured.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
notes: On 22 November 2018, fighters of the PK5 militia clashed with security forces in the 5th district of Bangui, leaving 4 killed (including a taxi driver) and 20 injured. Some reports alleged that CAR forces of the central office for the repression of banditry destroyed a PK5 base in the 5th district and gained control of the site but PK5 militiamen denied this version.
On 21 November 2018, militiamen from Bangui's Miskine Christian neighbourhood carried out a knife attack targeting 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood. This sparked wider clashes.

On 21 November 2018, the targeting of 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood by Miskime militiamen sparked wider clashes in the area, which involved gunfire and grenades, and resulted in the death of 2 people and the injury of 6.
On 20 November 2018, fire exchange in Bangui's PK5 area was reported. Although the source left the actors unidentified, it suggested that PK5 militiamen were likely to be involved.

On 20 November 2018, Muslim PK5 militiamen held a small protest in Bangui's PK5 area holding signs against Russian presence in the country. This took place after an attack on the HQs of PK5 leader 'Force' on Nov 17, which some attributed to a Russian drone.

assoc_actor_2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: On 17 November 2018, ex-Seleka militiamen opened fire (seemingly at no target) as they were passing through the town of Batangafo town (Batangafo, Ouham), prompting a response from Anti-balaka elements. 1 ex-Seleka fighter was reported killed and 10 injured before UN forces arrived and stopped the clashes.

On 17 November 2018, at 0200 GMT, unidentified gunmen attacked the HQs of Nimery Matar ('Force'), leader of the communal/vigilante PK5 militia, in the 3rd district of Bangui. Casualties were reported - unclear if fatalities or injuries.
On 17 November 2018, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in the Ouham region.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: On 17 November 2018, clashes erupted between two CAR military engineering units following a dispute regarding the security and financial conditions of their work. 3 soldiers were killed and 3 others injured.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Siriri fighters attacked a UN base in Gbambia at 2000 GMT, sparking clashes that lasted for 45 minutes. A Tanzanian peacekeeper was injured and died from his injuries in the hospital.
In the week of Nov 12, a merchant was killed in Sam-Ouandja by unidentified gunmen on the Ouada-Djalle-Sam-Ouandja road.

assoc_actor_2: Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic); Christian Group (Central African Republic)
notes: 15 November. After the UPC and Mujahedin militia had finished attacking the IDP camp in Alindao, Anti-Balaka fighters returned and looted the remaining goods in the camp.

assoc_actor_2: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Taxi Drivers (Central African Republic)
notes: 15 November. Anti-Balaka ambushed a Muslim moto-taxi driver at the outskirts of Alindao, killing two of his passengers.
01 - 30 November. During the month of November, 3R forces moved into Siriri territory in Nana Mambere, where they forcibly recruited Siriri members into 3R.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 15 November 2018, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.

notes: 31 October. Following two separate attacks on Muslims and Fulani the same morning (coded separately), the MPC, FPRC and armed Muslims attacked IDP camps, homes, the church and the market in Batangafo. IDP camps were targeted as the attackers suspected Anti-Balaka of hiding in them. Eleven people were killed and 37 were injured. Investigations that the attackers sought to permanently remove IDPs from the town by destroying the camps but the perpetrators instructed women and children IDPs to flee their huts before they were set on fire, elderly and disabled persons accounted for the majority of fatalities according to MSF.

actor1: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 26 October. The National Assembly removed Karim Mechassoua, the President of the Assembly. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. The following day, the CNDS (a coalition of ex-Seleka groups) urged all groups associated with the government to vacate the areas under their control within 48 hours, although a separate statement issued by FPRC denied this ultimatum.

29 September. An armed group kidnapped humanitarian staff between Kebe and Barya and looted their belongings. The aid workers were released later that day.
28 September: Participants in DDR programs protested in Bangui. The demonstrators demanded five million CFA francs and lamented that the DDR programs failed to help them secure employment.

27 September. Armed groups clashed around Nao. Over 1,700 civilians were displaced along the Gbambia-Nao road.
